natural problem: My school's Physics Club has 22 members.  It needs to select 3 officers: chairman, vice-chairman, and sergeant-at-arms.  Each person can hold at most one office.  Two of the members, Penelope and Quentin, will only be officers if the other one is also an officer.  (In other words, either both Penelope and Quentin are officers, or neither are.)  In how many ways can the club choose its officers?
natural solution: If both Penelope and Quentin are not officers, then there are 20 choices for chairman, 19 choices for vice-chairman, and 18 choices for sergeant-at-arms. There are $20\times 19\times 18=6840$ ways in this case.

If both are officers, Penelope can take one of the 3 positions, Quentin can take one of the 2 remaining positions, and one of the 20 remaining members can take the third position. There are $3\times 2\times 20=120$ ways in this case.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members total_cases cases_without_PQ cases_with_PQ :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 22"
and h1 : "cases_without_PQ = (members - 2) * (members - 3) * (members - 4) div 6"
and h2 : "cases_with_PQ = 2 * (members - 2)"
and h3 : "total_cases = cases_without_PQ + cases_with_PQ"
shows  "total_cases = 6960"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My school's Physics Club has 22 members.  It needs to select 3 officers: chairman, vice-chairman, and sergeant-at-arms.  Each person can hold at most one office.  Two of the members, Penelope and Quentin, will only be officers if the other one is also an officer.  (In other words, either both Penelope and Quentin are officers, or neither are.)  In how many ways can the club choose its officers? The final Answer is 6960
 ### Proof
 If both Penelope and Quentin are not officers, then there are 20 choices for chairman, 19 choices for vice-chairman, and 18 choices for sergeant-at-arms. There are $20\times 19\times 18=6840$ ways in this case.
 If both are officers, Penelope can take one of the 3 positions, Quentin can take one of the 2 remaining positions, and one of the 20 remaining members can take the third position. There are $3\times 2\times 20=120$ ways in this case.
 The answer is $6840+120=\boxed{6960}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes members total_cases cases_without_PQ cases_with_PQ :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 22"
and h1 : "cases_without_PQ = (members - 2) * (members - 3) * (members - 4) div 6"
and h2 : "cases_with_PQ = 2 * (members - 2)"
and h3 : "total_cases = cases_without_PQ + cases_with_PQ"
shows  "total_cases = 6960"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a group of 22 members, we want to form a committee. The total number of possible committees is given by the sum of the number of cases without two specific members, P and Q, and the cases with either P or Q (but not both). Find the total number of possible committees. The final answer is 6960.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members penelope_quentin others :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 22"
and h1 : "penelope_quentin = 2"
and h2 : "others = members - penelope_quentin"
and h3 : "3 * (3 - 1) * (others - 1) * (others - 2) + penelope_quentin * (others - 1) * (others - 2) = 6960"
shows  "card (all_possible_sets_of_officers members penelope_quentin others) = 6960"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members officers penelope_quentin :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 22"
and h1 : "officers = 3"
and h2 : "penelope_quentin = 2"
and h3 : "card {chairman, vice_chairman, sergeant_at_arms} = officers"
and h4 : "card {Penelope, Quentin} = penelope_quentin"
and h5 : "card {Penelope, Quentin, chairman, vice_chairman, sergeant_at_arms} = officers + penelope_quentin"
shows  "card {S. \<exists> chairman vice_chairman sergeant_at_arms. S = {chairman, vice_chairman, sergeant_at_arms} \<and> card S = officers \<and> (\<forall> P Q. {P, Q} = {Penelope, Quentin} \<longrightarrow> (P \<in> S \<longleftrightarrow> Q \<in> S))} = 6960"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_of_members num_of_officers num_of_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_of_members = 22"
and h1 : "num_of_officers = 3"
and h2 : "\<exists>penelope quentin. (penelope \<noteq> quentin) \<and>
           (\<forall>chairman vice_chairman sergeant_at_arms.
               (chairman \<noteq> vice_chairman) \<and> (chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and> (vice_chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and>
               (chairman = penelope \<and> vice_chairman = quentin \<or> chairman = quentin \<and> vice_chairman = penelope \<or> 
                chairman = penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms = quentin \<or> chairman = quentin \<and> sergeant_at_arms = penelope \<or>
                vice_chairman = penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms = quentin \<or> vice_chairman = quentin \<and> sergeant_at_arms = penelope \<or>
                chairman \<noteq> penelope \<and> chairman \<noteq> quentin \<and> vice_chairman \<noteq> penelope \<and> vice_chairman \<noteq> quentin \<and> 
                sergeant_at_arms \<noteq> penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms \<noteq> quentin))"
and h3 : "num_of_ways = card {chairman_vice_chairman_sergeant_at_arms_set. \<exists>penelope quentin.
           (penelope \<noteq> quentin) \<and> (\<forall>chairman vice_chairman sergeant_at_arms.
           (chairman \<noteq> vice_chairman) \<and> (chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and> (vice_chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and>
           (chairman = penelope \<and> vice_chairman = quentin \<or> chairman = quentin \<and> vice_chairman = penelope \<or> 
            chairman = penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms = quentin \<or> chairman = quentin \<and> sergeant_at_arms = penelope \<or>
            vice_chairman = penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms = quentin \<or> vice_chairman = quentin \<and> sergeant_at_arms = penelope \<or>
            chairman \<noteq> penelope \<and> chairman \<noteq> quentin \<and> vice_chairman \<noteq> penelope \<and> vice_chairman \<noteq> quentin \<and> 
            sergeant_at_arms \<noteq> penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms \<noteq> quentin))}"
shows  "num_of_ways = 6960"

 If both are officers, Penelope can take one of the 3 positions, Quentin can take one of the 2 remaining positions, and one of the 20 remaining members can take the third position. There are $3\times 2\times 20=120$ ways in this case.
 The answer is $6840+120=\boxed{6960}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes num_of_members num_of_officers num_of_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_of_members = 22"
and h1 : "num_of_officers = 3"
and h2 : "\<exists>penelope quentin. (penelope \<noteq> quentin) \<and>
           (\<forall>chairman vice_chairman sergeant_at_arms.
               (chairman \<noteq> vice_chairman) \<and> (chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and> (vice_chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and>
               (chairman = penelope \<and> vice_chairman = quentin \<or> chairman = quentin \<and> vice_chairman = penelope \<or> 
                chairman = penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms = quentin \<or> chairman = quentin \<and> sergeant_at_arms = penelope \<or>
                vice_chairman = penelope \<and> sergeant_at_arms = quentin \<or> vice_chairman = quentin \<and> sergeant_at_arms = penelope \<or>
                chairman \<noteq> penelope \<and> chairman \<noteq> quentin \<and> vice_chairman \<noteq> penelope \<and> vice_chairman \<noteq> quentin \<and>

           (chairman \<noteq> vice_chairman) \<and> (chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and> (vice_chairman \<noteq> sergeant_at_arms) \<and>
           (chairman = penelope \<and> vice_chairman = quentin \<or> chairman = quentin \<and> vice_chairman = penelope \<or>

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 22"
and h1 : "two_members_together n = (n - 2) * (n - 3) * (n - 4) / 6"
and h2 : "two_members_separate n = (n - 2) * (n - 3) * (n - 4) * 3"
and h3 : "total_ways n = h1 n + h2 n"
shows  "total_ways n = 6960"

 The answer is $6840+120=\boxed{6960}.$
 *)

fixes n :: nat

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_members p_q_members remaining_members :: nat
and choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "total_members = 22"
and h1 : "p_q_members = 2"
and h2 : "remaining_members = total_members - p_q_members"
and h3 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
and h4 : "choose total_members 3 = choose p_q_members 2 * choose remaining_members 1 + choose remaining_members 3"
shows  "choose total_members 3 = 6960"
a_5.formal solution:

 If both are officers, Penelope can take one of the 3 positions, Quentin can take one of the 2 remaining positions, and one of the 20 remaining members can take the third position. There are $3\times 2\times 20=120$ ways in this case.
 The answer is $6840+120=\boxed{6960}.$
 *)

fixes total_members p_q_members remaining_members :: nat
and choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

and h1 : "p_q_members = 2"
and h2 : "remaining_members = total_members - p_q_members"
and h3 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
and h4 : "choose total_members 3 = choose p_q_members 2 * choose remaining_members 1 + choose remaining_members 3"
shows  "choose total_members 3 = 6960"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 22"
and h1 : "card {chairman, vice_chairman, sergeant_at_arms} = 3"
and h2 : "card {Penelope, Quentin} = 2"
shows  "card {f. \<exists> C V S. f = (C, V, S) \<and> card C = 1 \<and> card V = 1 \<and> card S = 1 \<and> C \<inter> V = {} \<and> V \<inter> S = {} \<and> S \<inter> C = {} \<and> ((Penelope \<in> C \<union> V \<union> S) = (Quentin \<in> C \<union> V \<union> S))} = 6960"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My school's Physics Club has 22 members.  It needs to select 3 officers: chairman, vice-chairman, and sergeant-at-arms.  Each person can hold at most one office. fixes n :: nat

shows  "card {f. \<exists> C V S. f = (C, V, S) \<and> card C = 1 \<and> card V = 1 \<and> card S = 1 \<and> C \<inter> V = {} \<and> V \<inter> S = {} \<and> S \<inter> C = {} \<and> ((Penelope \<in> C \<union> V \<union> S) = (Quentin \<in> C \<union> V \<union> S))} = 6960"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members :: nat and P_Q_cond :: bool and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 22"
and h1 : "P_Q_cond = (\<exists> P Q. (\<forall> C V S. C \<noteq> V \<and> V \<noteq> S \<and> C \<noteq> S))"
and h2 : "ways = (if P_Q_cond then (members - 2) * (members - 3) * (members - 4) + (members - 2) * (members - 3) else 0)"
shows  "ways = 6960"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My school's Physics Club has 22 members.  It needs to select 3 officers: chairman, vice-chairman, and sergeant-at-arms.  Each person can hold at most one office.  Two of the members, Penelope and Quentin, will only be officers if the other one is also an officer.  (In other words, either both Penelope and Quentin are officers, or neither are.)  In how many ways can the club choose its officers? The final Answer is 6960
 ### Proof
 If both Penelope and Quentin are not officers, then there are 20 choices for chairman, 19 choices for vice-chairman, and 18 choices for sergeant-at-arms. There are $20\times 19\times 18=6840$ ways in this case.
 If both are officers, Penelope can take one of the 3 positions, Quentin can take one of the 2 remaining positions, and one of the 20 remaining members can take the third position. There are $3\times 2\times 20=120$ ways in this case.
 The answer is $6840+120=\boxed{6960}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes members :: nat and P_Q_cond :: bool and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 22"
and h1 : "P_Q_cond = (\<exists> P Q. (\<forall> C V S. C \<noteq> V \<and> V \<noteq> S \<and> C \<noteq> S))"
and h2 : "ways = (if P_Q_cond then (members - 2) * (members - 3) * (members - 4) + (members - 2) * (members - 3) else 0)"
shows  "ways = 6960"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a group of 22 members, there exist two distinct subgroups P and Q such that no member is in both P and Q, and no member is in neither P nor Q. Find the number of ways to select three distinct members, one from each of the following categories: a member in P only, a member in Q only, and a member in neither P nor Q. The final answer is 6960.
